<script type="text/javascript">
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var ajax_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php';	
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
</script>

	<title>Operation Rewrite: Chinese-Speaking Threat Actors Deploy BadIIS in a Wide Scale SEO Poisoning Campaign</title>
	<meta name="description" content="SEO poisoning campaign &quot;Operation Rewrite” uses a malicious IIS module called BadIIS to redirect users to unwanted websites." />

<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/malware/"/>
<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Yoav Zemah"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/"/>
<meta property="og:author_image_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/unit-news-meta.svg"/>
<meta name="post_tags" content="CL-UNK-1037,SEO poisoning,web shells"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Operation Rewrite: Chinese-Speaking Threat Actors Deploy BadIIS in a Wide Scale SEO Poisoning Campaign","name":"Operation Rewrite: Chinese-Speaking Threat Actors Deploy BadIIS in a Wide Scale SEO Poisoning Campaign","description":"SEO poisoning campaign \"Operation Rewrite\u201d uses a malicious IIS module called BadIIS to redirect users to unwanted websites.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/operation-rewrite-seo-poisoning-campaign\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/operation-rewrite-seo-poisoning-campaign\/","datePublished":"September 22, 2025","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nIn March 2025, we uncovered a search engine optimization (SEO) poisoning campaign. Based on the infrastructure and linguistic artifacts discovered, we assess with high confidence that a Chinese-speaking threat actor operates this campaign. We call this \u201cOperation Rewrite\u201d in reference to the English translation of one of the object names in the threat actor\u2019s code.\r\n\r\nWe track this cluster of activity as CL-UNK-1037. Our analysis revealed infrastructure and architectural overlaps with the publicly tracked \u201cGroup 9\u201d threat cluster and the \u201cDragonRank\u201d campaign.\r\n\r\nTo perform SEO poisoning, attackers manipulate search engine results to trick people into visiting unexpected or unwanted websites (e.g., gambling and porn websites) for financial gain. This attack used a malicious native Internet Information Services (IIS) module called BadIIS. This module intercepts and alters web traffic, using legitimate compromised servers to serve malicious content to visitors. The compromised web server then acts as a reverse proxy \u2014 an intermediary server getting content from other servers and presenting it as its own.\r\n\r\nAnalysis of the malware's configuration reveals a clear geographic focus on East and Southeast Asia. This targeting is evident in the module's code, which includes specific logic for regional search engines.\r\n\r\nThe attackers behind this campaign employ a toolkit that extends beyond the BadIIS module. We found undocumented variants, including lightweight ASP.NET page handlers, managed .NET IIS modules and an all-in-one PHP script.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed above through the following products and services:\r\n\r\n \tAdvanced WildFire\r\n \tAdvanced URL Filtering and Advanced DNS Security\r\n \tCortex XDR\r\n\r\nIf you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the Unit 42 Incident Response team.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRelated Unit 42 Topics\r\nSEO Poisoning, Web Shells\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBackground of BadIIS Malware\r\nFirst profiled in 2021, BadIIS is the umbrella term for malicious native IIS modules. These modules integrate directly into a web server's request pipeline and inherit the web server's full privileges. Due to this privileged position within the web server, a single implant can perform a wide range of actions. This includes the ability to:\r\n\r\n \tInject JavaScript or iframes\r\n \tTunnel traffic through a built-in reverse proxy\r\n \tFire 302 redirects that trick search engine crawlers\r\n \tSteal sensitive information\r\n\r\nESET researchers were the first to name these modules BadIIS [PDF] and to map their variants.\r\nThe Role of SEO Poisoning\r\nAttackers use the BadIIS malware to maliciously manipulate search engine results to direct traffic to their chosen destination. This technique is called SEO poisoning. Instead of building a new website's reputation from scratch, which is a slow and challenging process, the attackers compromise established, legitimate websites that already have a good domain reputation.\r\n\r\nTo poison search results, attackers inject the compromised website with keywords and phrases that frequently appear in internet searches. This manipulation alters the site's SEO, making it appear in search results for a broader range of popular queries. As a result, the website's ranking improves for these commonly used terms, bringing more traffic to the now-poisoned site.\r\nThe Attack Flow: A High-Level Walkthrough\r\nIn the following sections, we outline how BadIIS leverages SEO poisoning in the flow of an attack. This campaign has two primary phases: luring the search engine and trapping the victim.\r\nPhase 1: The Poisoned Lure\r\nThe attacker\u2019s goal in this phase is to cause a search engine to index the compromised website for certain keywords.\r\n\r\n \tIncoming HTTP Request: A search engine crawler visits the compromised www.victim[.]com web server.\r\n \tBadIIS Module Intercepts: The module inspects the User-Agent header. If the header contains a keyword from its configuration list, the module identifies the visitor as a search engine crawler.\r\n \tC2 Communication and Response: The module contacts its command and control (C2) server to fetch the poisoned content. The C2 responds with custom, keyword-stuffed HTML that is designed purely for SEO.\r\n \tFinal Output: The BadIIS module serves this malicious HTML to the search engine crawler. As a result, the search engine indexes www.victim[.]com as a relevant source for the terms found in the C2 response, effectively poisoning the search results.\r\n\r\nPhase 2: Springing the Redirection Trap\r\nNow that the lure is set, the attacker waits for a victim to click the poisoned search result.\r\n\r\n \tIncoming HTTP Request: Someone searches for a keyword that appears in the module\u2019s configuration list and clicks the poisoned search result, which points to www.victim[.]com.\r\n \tBadIIS Module Intercepts: If the module doesn't flag this request as a search engine crawler, it then inspects the Referer header. If it identifies the referrer as a search engine, it flags the visitor as a victim.\r\n \tC2 Communication and Response: The module contacts the C2 server to retrieve malicious content. This is typically a redirect to a scam website.\r\n \tFinal Output: The BadIIS module seamlessly proxies this redirect to the victim's browser. The victim, who expected to visit www.victim[.]com, is immediately sent to the attacker-controlled scam content.\r\n\r\nTechnical Analysis of CL-UNK-1037 Arsenal and Infrastructure\r\nWe investigated a security breach in which attackers gained access to a web server. After gaining an initial foothold, the attackers pivoted to multiple production web servers, domain controllers and other high\u2011value hosts. They then:\r\n\r\n \tDeployed additional web shells on each compromised web server\r\n \tCreated remote scheduled tasks to move laterally across the network and executed reconnaissance commands and additional tool sets on target machines\r\n \tCreated new local user accounts on compromised systems\r\n\r\nExfiltrating Source Code Over the Web\r\nThe attackers used their deployed web shells to compress the entire web application source code directory into ZIP archives. They then moved the archives into web-accessible paths.\r\n\r\nThis strongly indicates that the attackers intended to retrieve the ZIP archives over HTTP at a later stage. After exfiltrating the source code, the attackers uploaded several new DLLs to the compromised web servers, silently registering them as IIS modules.\r\n\r\nFurther analysis revealed these DLLs to be BadIIS implants.\r\nThe Initially Discovered BadIIS Sample\r\nCloser investigation into the IIS module\u2019s DLL revealed that it exports the RegisterModule function. This function is called by IIS when the module is loaded, and it:\r\n\r\n \tCreates an instance of an object named chongxiede\r\n \tInvokes IIS's SetRequestNotifications\r\n \tRegisters handlers for OnBeginRequest and OnSendResponse\r\n\r\nThese methods allow the module to secretly manipulate webpage content by intercepting the incoming HTTP request before any processing begins and again right before the final response is sent.\r\n\r\nOnce an instance of the chongxiede object is created, its constructor pulls the implant\u2019s encrypted configuration from the DLL's data section and XOR-decrypts each one in place. Chongxiede is the Chinese Pinyin transliteration for the word \u91cd\u5199 (ch\u00f3ng xi\u011b), which machine translates to \u201crewrite\u201d or \u201coverwrite.\u201d Figure 1 shows the decryption process.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_158105\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"368\"] Figure 1. The decryption process of the implant\u2019s configuration.[\/caption]\r\nBadIIS Configuration and Inner Workings\r\nThe initial configuration of the implant consists of:\r\n\r\n \tReferer\/user-agent keywords list: google|yahoo|bing|viet|coccoc|timkhap|tuugo\r\n \tFirst C2 server: hxxp:\/\/404.008php[.]com\/\r\n \tSecond C2 server: hxxp:\/\/103.6.235[.]26\/\r\n\r\nThis configuration data shows a targeted strategy. While the keyword list includes common global search engines like Google and Bing, the presence of language-specific services exposes the attacker's targets:\r\n\r\n \tC\u1ed1c C\u1ed1c\r\n \tTimkhap\r\n \tviet\r\n\r\nThe first two terms are Vietnamese search engines, while the third term relates to any Vietnam-related searches. This specific focus on Vietnam's digital ecosystem demonstrates a clear and strategic targeting of the country's digital landscape.\r\n\r\nThe module uses this configuration to execute its core logic at runtime. If the HTTP request's User-Agent header matches a keyword from the same list, the module identifies the visitor as a search engine crawler and executes its poisoning phase. It contacts the C2 server to retrieve a malicious, SEO-optimized HTML webpage and serves it as the response.\r\n\r\nFigure 2 displays an actual payload delivered by the C2 server. The payload contains the malicious HTML and a series of links that trick the search engine into scraping and indexing them.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_158116\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 2. The SEO poison payload from the C2 server.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe mechanism first builds a lure and then springs the trap. The lure is built by attackers feeding manipulated content to search engine crawlers. This makes the compromised website rank for additional terms to which it would otherwise have no connection.\r\n\r\nFor instance, as Figure 2 above shows, the payload is filled with links containing popular Vietnamese search queries. A key example is x\u00f4i l\u1ea1c tv tr\u1ef1c ti\u1ebfp b\u00f3ng \u0111\u00e1 h\u00f4m nay, which translates to \u201cx\u00f4i l\u1ea1c tv live football today.\u201d This is a popular search for an illegal soccer streaming service.\r\n\r\nRanking the compromised server for this term allows attackers to exploit its credibility and reputation. Figure 3 displays a Google search result for this string of terms, showing that a government entity in Southeast Asia was compromised to serve scam content.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_158127\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"983\"] Figure 3. Google search index of a compromised government entity.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nConversely, when an incoming HTTP request's Referer header contains any of the keywords from its configuration, the module flags it as a genuine user. In this case, the module contacts a C2 server and proxies its content directly to the victim's browser.\r\n\r\nFigure 4 shows an actual proxied payload sent from the C2. This figure shows that the compromised web server redirects unsuspecting visitors to a betting site.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_158138\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"737\"] Figure 4. The payload from the C2 server: a loading page that redirects visitors to a betting website.[\/caption]\r\nAdditional Samples and Infrastructure\r\nA significant clue to the functionality and likely origin of the implant can be found in its C++ class name: chongxiede. As noted above, this is the Chinese Pinyin transliteration for the word \u91cd\u5199 (ch\u00f3ng xi\u011b), which machine translates to \u201crewrite\u201d or \u201coverwrite.\u201d This linguistic artifact served as a pivot point in our investigation and allowed us to expand our research, ultimately leading us to additional samples and infrastructure-related threat activity.\r\n\r\nWe uncovered a suite of related native IIS modules that share handler registrations and initialization logic. Several of these new samples pointed to familiar C2 domains, variants of the 008php[.]com domain family, while others introduced previously unseen infrastructure. Figure 5 shows the infrastructure and the connections between the samples.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_158149\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 5. The newly found BadIIS samples and infrastructure.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nWe analyzed these related samples, then extracted and decrypted their embedded configurations. This analysis revealed a wider network of C2 servers and URLs that were not previously associated with this campaign. Our investigation into this newly discovered infrastructure revealed three additional variants, which demonstrate an expansion of the threat actor's toolkit, and capabilities beyond the native IIS module framework.\r\n\r\nBecause of the significance of the information gained from this linguistic artifact, we termed the campaign \u201cOperation Rewrite.\u201d\r\nThree New Flavors for the BadIIS Module\r\nFirst Variant: ASP.NET Gateway\r\nThe first variant we discovered was not a native module at all, but a simple ASP.NET page handler. This script-based variant uses a different technique to achieve the same goal of SEO poisoning as the core BadIIS module.\r\n\r\nInstead of hooking directly into the IIS pipeline, the ASP.NET page contains all the malicious logic within its Page_Load event. When a victim requests the server for the page, the page checks the visitor's HTTP_REFERER to identify and redirect traffic from search engines, cloaking its real purpose. For all other traffic, it acts as a gateway, proxying malicious content from a remote C2 server.\r\n\r\nThis is a lighter, more flexible alternative to the main BadIIS module, likely for quick deployment on less-critical compromised servers. Figure 6 shows the Page_Load function of the ASP.NET variant.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_158160\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"671\"] Figure 6. The Page_Load function of the ASP.NET variant.[\/caption]\r\nSecond Variant: Managed IIS Module\r\nThe second variant achieved the same goal as the native IIS module, but it was implemented as a managed .NET IIS module. This C# variant leverages ASP.NET integration within IIS. It hooks into the server requests pipeline, granting it the ability to inspect and modify every request that passes through the application.\r\n\r\nThis module performs SEO poisoning through two primary functions:\r\n\r\n \t404 Error Hijacking: This module intercepts 404 errors when a search engine crawls a non-existent link containing keywords from a hard-coded list. It then serves a custom scam page from a C2 server, resulting in search engines indexing the attacker's content under the victim's trusted domain.\r\n \tInjecting Live Content: When the module detects a search engine crawler viewing a real page that returns a 200 OK response, it dynamically injects spam links and keywords from a different C2 server. This action alters the existing page's search ranking, without changing the content that is visible to regular users.\r\n\r\nThird Variant: All-in-One PHP Script\r\nThe third variant is a PHP-based script that combines user redirection and dynamic SEO poisoning. Rather than integrating into IIS, this script is a standalone PHP front-controller. It uses a simple referer, user agent and URL-pattern checks to decide exactly what to serve.\r\n\r\n \tChecking mobile user requests\r\n\r\nFor visitors arriving from a Google search on a mobile device, the script performs an additional check. If the requested URL path contains a keyword from a hard-coded list (i.e., \u201cgame\u201d or \u201cvideo\u201d) it acts as a proxy. The script silently contacts a hard-coded C2 URL, retrieves the content and serves it directly to the victim, who remains unaware of the substitution.\r\n\r\n \tPoisoning Googlebot SEO\r\n\r\nWhen the script detects Googlebot, it initiates a two-stage process to poison the site's search engine ranking.\r\n\r\n \t\r\n\r\n \tSitemap generator: First, the script fetches a list of page names from the C2 server and presents them to Googlebot as a valid XML sitemap full of fake URLs.\r\n \tContent rewriter: When Googlebot crawls these fake URLs, the script's second stage activates, becoming a content rewriter. The script fetches an HTML template from another C2 and injects keywords from the URL into the page's title and headings. The result is an optimized spam page, designed to rank high in search results.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nExploring the Threat Actors\u2019 Origins\r\nWe analyzed linguistic clues and infrastructure overlaps to determine the origins of the threat actors behind CL-UNK-1037. We attribute this activity cluster, with high confidence, to Chinese-speaking attackers. Additionally, we link this cluster with moderate confidence to Group 9 and with low confidence to DragonRank.\r\nChinese-Speaking Threat Actors\r\nSeveral artifacts suggest the involvement of a Chinese-speaking threat actor. As stated previously, the native module's chongxiede object name is a Pinyin term. The PHP variant contained further linguistic evidence: numerous code comments written in simplified Chinese characters.\r\n\r\nFigure 7 shows the comments written in simplified Chinese in the PHP variant, along with their English translations.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_158171\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"708\"] Figure 7. The start of the PHP variant.[\/caption]\r\nCode Design and Infrastructure Overlaps with Group 9\r\nThe BadIIS internal architecture design bears similarities to variants previously used by Group 9, as described by ESET in their whitepaper. These similarities include:\r\n\r\n \tUsing the RegisterModule function to initialize the module\u2019s components\r\n \tUsing the OnBeginRequest and OnSendResponse handlers to intercept and modify web traffic\r\n\r\nThis parallel design suggests that the attackers are building their implants using a shared codebase or design pattern.\r\n\r\nThe direct overlap in C2 infrastructure across three separate domains solidifies the connection to Group 9. The C2 servers hard coded in the BadIIS samples included:\r\n\r\n \t404.008php[.]com\r\n \t404.yyphw[.]com\r\n \t404.300bt[.]com\r\n\r\nThese servers directly correspond to domains used by Group 9. Specifically, ESET observed Group 9 using the following subdomains:\r\n\r\n \tqp.008php[.]com\r\n \tfcp.yyphw[.]com\r\n \tsc.300bt[.]com\r\n\r\nFigure 8 illustrates this infrastructure.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_158182\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"889\"] Figure 8. The infrastructure overlaps between the new samples and Group 9.[\/caption]\r\nPossible Connection to DragonRank\r\nIn addition to the direct links to Group 9, we observed several similarities to the DragonRank campaign. As detailed in Cisco's Talos article, they attribute DragonRank to a Chinese-speaking threat actor that shares similarities with ESET's Group 9.\r\n\r\nAlthough we found no infrastructure overlap between CL-UNK-1037 and the DragonRank campaign, we did observe the following similarities:\r\n\r\n \tTool set: Similar core functionality and logical malware flow, using different implementations. Both variants are SEO and proxy tools.\r\n \tURI structure: A recurring zz pattern in the C2 URLs. While the pattern is used differently in each campaign, we assess that this could be the result of tool set evolution or upgrades over time.\r\n\r\nConclusion\r\nOur investigation into the Operation Rewrite SEO poisoning campaign uncovered a Chinese-speaking threat actor using a playbook of custom implants. The threat actor tailored all the implants to the goal of manipulating search engine results and controlling the flow of traffic.\r\n\r\nWe assess with high confidence that a Chinese-speaking actor is operating this activity, based on direct linguistic evidence, as well as infrastructure and architecture links between this actor and the Group 9 cluster. Our research also revealed several similarities with the DragonRank campaign.\r\n\r\nSecurity teams and network defenders can leverage the analysis and indicators in this report to enhance their threat detection and hunting capabilities, strengthening their security against these and similar threats.\r\nPalo Alto Networks Protection and Mitigation\r\n\r\n \tAdvanced URL Filtering and Advanced DNS Security identify known domains and URLs associated with this activity as malicious.\r\n \tCortex XDR prevents the threats described in this blog by employing the Malware Prevention Engine. This approach combines several layers of protection, including Advanced WildFire, Behavioral Threat Protection and the Local Analysis module, to prevent both known and unknown malware from causing harm to endpoints.\r\n\r\nIf you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the Unit 42 Incident Response team or call:\r\n\r\n \tNorth America: Toll Free: +1 (866) 486-4842 (866.4.UNIT42)\r\n \tUK: +44.20.3743.3660\r\n \tEurope and Middle East: +31.20.299.3130\r\n \tAsia: +65.6983.8730\r\n \tJapan: +81.50.1790.0200\r\n \tAustralia: +61.2.4062.7950\r\n \tIndia: 000 800 050 45107\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the Cyber Threat Alliance.\r\nIndicators of Compromise\r\nBadIIS implants SHA256 hashes:\r\n\r\n \t01a616e25f1ac661a7a9c244fd31736188ceb5fce8c1a5738e807fdbef70fd60\r\n \tbc3bba91572379e81919b9e4d2cbe3b0aa658a97af116e2385b99b610c22c08c\r\n \t5aa684e90dd0b85f41383efe89dddb2d43ecbdaf9c1d52c40a2fdf037fb40138\r\n \tc5455c43f6a295392cf7db66c68f8c725029f88e089ed01e3de858a114f0764f\r\n \t82096c2716a4de687b3a09b638e39cc7c12959bf380610d5f8f9ac9cddab64d7\r\n <script>var $ = jQuery;</script>

    <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

            <script src="https://assets.adobedtm.com/9273d4aedcd2/0d76ae0322d7/launch-425c423d843b.min.js" async></script>
            <script type="text/javascript" src="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/content/dam/pan/en_US/includes/attribution.js"></script>


<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x
u=-1===u.indexOf("url(")?"url("+u+")":u,1===d.length?t.style.backgroundImage=u:t.setAttribute("style",(t.getAttribute("style")||"")+"background-image: "+u+"; background-image: -webkit-image-set("+d+"); background-image: image-set("+d+")")}t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class")&&t.classList.toggle(t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class"))},loaded:function(){}};function A(t){t.setAttribute("data-loaded",!0)}var m=function(t){return"true"===t.getAttribute("data-loaded")},v=function(t){var e=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:document;return t instanceof Element?[t]:t instanceof NodeList?t:e.querySelectorAll(t)};return function(){var r,a,o=0<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[0]?arguments[0]:".lozad",t=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:{},e=Object.assign({},f,t),i=e.root,n=e.rootMargin,d=e.threshold,u=e.load,g=e.loaded,s=void 0;"undefined"!=typeof window&&window.IntersectionObserver&&(s=new IntersectionObserver((r=u,a=g,function(t,e){t.forEach(function(t){(0<t.intersectionRatio||t.isIntersecting)&&(e.unobserve(t.target),m(t.target)||(r(t.target),A(t.target),a(t.target)))})}),{root:i,rootMargin:n,threshold:d}));for(var c,l=v(o,i),b=0;b<l.length;b++)(c=l[b]).getAttribute("data-placeholder-background")&&(c.style.background=c.getAttribute("data-placeholder-background"));return{observe:function(){for(var t=v(o,i),e=0;e<t.length;e++)m(t[e])||(s?s.observe(t[e]):(u(t[e]),A(t[e]),g(t[e])))},triggerLoad:function(t){m(t)||(u(t),A(t),g(t))},observer:s}}});

</script>

    <ul id="menu-primary-navigation" class="main-menu d-sm-flex font-weight-medium"><li id="menu-item-97290" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-97290"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tools/">Tools</a></li>

<div class="panClean pan-template-home" id="main-nav-menu-cont" style="display:none;">
    <div class="cleanHeader mainNavigationComp baseComponent parbase">
        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}        
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
            if( pcontainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                referer = 'CloudCortex' ;
            }
            else{
                referer = 'Cortex' ;
            }	    
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            if( nContainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                                referer = 'CloudCortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","CloudCortex");
                            }
                            else{
                                referer = 'Cortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                            }                            
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "CloudCortex" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=prisma&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=cortexcloud&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexcloudsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=cortex&domain=en';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=sase&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=unit42&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        //var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=ngfw&domain=en'; 
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
            observer_lozad.observe();
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'CloudCortex' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cloudcortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->



<main class="main">
    
<section class="section section--article">
        <div class="pa article-banner" style="background-image:url('https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/06_Nation-State-cyberattacks_1920x900.jpg')">
          <div class="l-container">

					<span>English</span>
					<span class="icon-down"></span>

			              <div class="l-breadcrumbs"> 
              <ul> <li> <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com" role="link" title="Threat Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="operation-rewrite-seo-poisoning-campaign:hero:breadcrumb:Threat Research">Threat Research Center</a></li><li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" title="Threat Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="operation-rewrite-seo-poisoning-campaign:hero:breadcrumb:Threat Research">Threat Research</a></li><li class="is-current"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/malware/" role="link" title="Malware" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="operation-rewrite-seo-poisoning-campaign:hero:breadcrumb:Malware">Malware</a></li> </ul>
            </div>            <div class="ab__title">
              <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/malware/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="operation-rewrite-seo-poisoning-campaign:hero:Malware"><span class="ab-title__pre">Malware</span></a> 
              <h1>Operation Rewrite: Chinese-Speaking Threat Actors Deploy BadIIS in a Wide Scale SEO Poisoning Campaign</h1>
              <div class="ab__video">
              <span class="duration"> 
                <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-clock.svg" alt="Clock Icon"><span class="span-reading-time rt-reading-time"><span class="rt-label rt-prefix"></span> <span class="rt-time"> 12</span> <span class="rt-label rt-postfix"></span></span> min read              </span>
                              </div>          
              <div class="ab-lc__wrapper">
                <span class="ab-title__pre">Related Products</span><div class="ab__link-cards"><a class="l-linkcard is-blue"       </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <h2><a id="post-158093-_4lt92rr5muov"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>In March 2025, we uncovered a search engine optimization (SEO) poisoning campaign. Based on the infrastructure and linguistic artifacts discovered, we assess with high confidence that a Chinese-speaking threat actor operates this campaign. We call this “Operation Rewrite” in reference to the English translation of one of the object names in the threat actor’s code.</p>
<p>We track this cluster of activity as <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit-42-attribution-framework/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">CL-UNK-1037</a>. Our analysis revealed infrastructure and architectural overlaps with the publicly tracked “Group 9” threat cluster and the “DragonRank” campaign.</p>
<p>To perform SEO poisoning, attackers manipulate search engine results to trick people into visiting unexpected or unwanted websites (e.g., gambling and porn websites) for financial gain. This attack used a malicious native Internet Information Services (IIS) module called BadIIS. This module intercepts and alters web traffic, using legitimate compromised servers to serve malicious content to visitors. The compromised web server then acts as a reverse proxy — an intermediary server getting content from other servers and presenting it as its own.</p>
<p>Analysis of the malware's configuration reveals a clear geographic focus on East and Southeast Asia. This targeting is evident in the module's code, which includes specific logic for regional search engines.</p>
<p>The attackers behind this campaign employ a toolkit that extends beyond the BadIIS module. We found undocumented variants, including lightweight ASP.NET page handlers, managed .NET IIS modules and an all-in-one PHP script.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed above through the following products and services:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a></li>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-url-filtering/administration" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced DNS Security</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a></li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a>.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/seo-poisoning/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>SEO Poisoning</b></a>, <strong><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/web-shells/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Web Shells</a></strong></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-158093-_j7dygsrnweuy"></a>Background of BadIIS Malware</h2>
<p>First profiled in 2021, BadIIS is the umbrella term for malicious <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/iis/get-started/introduction-to-iis/iis-modules-overview" target="_blank" rel="noopener">native IIS modules</a>. These modules integrate directly into a web server's request pipeline and inherit the web server's full privileges. Due to this privileged position within the web server, a single implant can perform a wide range of actions. This includes the ability to:</p>
<ul>
<li>Inject JavaScript or iframes</li>
<li>Tunnel traffic through a built-in reverse proxy</li>
<li>Fire 302 redirects that trick search engine crawlers</li>
<li>Steal sensitive information</li>
</ul>
<p>ESET researchers were the first to <a href="https://web-assets.esetstatic.com/wls/2021/08/eset_anatomy_native_iis_malware.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">name these modules BadIIS [PDF]</a> and to map their variants.</p>
<h3><a id="post-158093-_x6nx3xxuum7a"></a>The Role of SEO Poisoning</h3>
<p>Attackers use the BadIIS malware to maliciously manipulate search engine results to direct traffic to their chosen destination. This technique is called SEO poisoning. Instead of building a new website's reputation from scratch, which is a slow and challenging process, the attackers compromise established, legitimate websites that already have a good domain reputation.</p>
<p>To poison search results, attackers inject the compromised website with keywords and phrases that frequently appear in internet searches. This manipulation alters the site's SEO, making it appear in search results for a broader range of popular queries. As a result, the website's ranking improves for these commonly used terms, bringing more traffic to the now-poisoned site.</p>
<h3><a id="post-158093-_b3oc9r8htk4k"></a>The Attack Flow: A High-Level Walkthrough</h3>
<p>In the following sections, we outline how BadIIS leverages SEO poisoning in the flow of an attack. This campaign has two primary phases: luring the search engine and trapping the victim.</p>
<h4><a id="post-158093-_dynuhqv5h99b"></a>Phase 1: The Poisoned Lure</h4>
<p>The attacker’s goal in this phase is to cause a search engine to index the compromised website for certain keywords.</p>
<ol>
<li><strong>Incoming HTTP Request:</strong> A search engine crawler visits the compromised <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">www.victim[.]com</span> web server.</li>
<li><strong>BadIIS Module Intercepts:</strong> The module inspects the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">User-Agent</span> header. If the header contains a keyword from its configuration list, the module identifies the visitor as a search engine crawler.</li>
<li><strong>C2 Communication and Response:</strong> The module contacts its command and control (C2) server to fetch the poisoned content. The C2 responds with custom, keyword-stuffed HTML that is designed purely for SEO.</li>
<li><strong>Final Output: </strong>The BadIIS module serves this malicious HTML to the search engine crawler. As a result, the search engine indexes <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">www.victim[.]com</span> as a relevant source for the terms found in the C2 response, effectively poisoning the search results.</li>
</ol>
<h4><a id="post-158093-_w9ywknk2e12z"></a>Phase 2: Springing the Redirection Trap</h4>
<p>Now that the lure is set, the attacker waits for a victim to click the poisoned search result.</p>
<ol>
<li><strong>Incoming HTTP Request:</strong> Someone searches for a keyword that appears in the module’s configuration list and clicks the poisoned search result, which points to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">www.victim[.]com</span>.</li>
<li><strong>BadIIS Module Intercepts:</strong> If the module doesn't flag this request as a search engine crawler, it then inspects the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Referer</span> header. If it identifies the referrer as a search engine, it flags the visitor as a victim.</li>
<li><strong>C2 Communication and Response:</strong> The module contacts the C2 server to retrieve malicious content. This is typically a redirect to a scam website.</li>
<li><strong>Final Output:</strong> The BadIIS module seamlessly proxies this redirect to the victim's browser. The victim, who expected to visit <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">www.victim[.]com</span>, is immediately sent to the attacker-controlled scam content.</li>
</ol>
<h2><a id="post-158093-_eq0u8whj2r7m"></a>Technical Analysis of CL-UNK-1037 Arsenal and Infrastructure</h2>
<p>We investigated a security breach in which attackers gained access to a web server. After gaining an initial foothold, the attackers pivoted to multiple production web servers, domain controllers and other high‑value hosts. They then:</p>
<ul>
<li>Deployed additional web shells on each compromised web server</li>
<li>Created remote scheduled tasks to move laterally across the network and executed reconnaissance commands and additional tool sets on target machines</li>
<li>Created new local user accounts on compromised systems</li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-158093-_bnbgdot0hfn0"></a>Exfiltrating Source Code Over the Web</h3>
<p>The attackers used their deployed web shells to compress the entire web application source code directory into ZIP archives. They then moved the archives into web-accessible paths.</p>
<p>This strongly indicates that the attackers intended to retrieve the ZIP archives over HTTP at a later stage. After exfiltrating the source code, the attackers uploaded several new DLLs to the compromised web servers, silently registering them as IIS modules.</p>
<p>Further analysis revealed these DLLs to be <strong>BadIIS </strong>implants.</p>
<h3><a id="post-158093-_50xe94jyh6j7"></a>The Initially Discovered BadIIS Sample</h3>
<p>Closer investigation into the IIS module’s DLL revealed that it exports the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">RegisterModule</span> function. This function is called by IIS when the module is loaded, and it:</p>
<ul>
<li>Creates an instance of an object named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">chongxiede</span></li>
<li>Invokes IIS's <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">SetRequestNotifications</span></li>
<li>Registers handlers for <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">OnBeginRequest</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">OnSendResponse</span></li>
</ul>
<p>These methods allow the module to secretly manipulate webpage content by intercepting the incoming HTTP request before any processing begins and again right before the final response is sent.</p>
<p>Once an instance of the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">chongxiede</span> object is created, its constructor pulls the implant’s encrypted configuration from the DLL's data section and XOR-decrypts each one in place. <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Chongxiede</span> is the Chinese Pinyin transliteration for the word 重写 (chóng xiě), which machine translates to “rewrite” or “overwrite.” Figure 1 shows the decryption process.</p>
<figure id="attachment_158105" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-158105" style="width: 368px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-158105 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-190375-158093-1.png" alt="Image displaying a snippet of computer code in a text editor with syntax highlighting, involving C/C++ programming language functions and variables, related to encryption processes." width="368" height="282" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-158105" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. The decryption process of the implant’s configuration.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-158093-_kamlqzpquhji"></a>BadIIS Configuration and Inner Workings</h3>
<p>The initial configuration of the implant consists of:</p>
<ul>
<li>Referer/user-agent keywords list: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">google|yahoo|bing|viet|coccoc|timkhap|tuugo</span></li>
<li>First C2 server: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://404.008php[.]com/</span></li>
<li>Second C2 server: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://103.6.235[.]26/</span></li>
</ul>
<p>This configuration data shows a targeted strategy. While the keyword list includes common global search engines like Google and Bing, the presence of language-specific services exposes the attacker's targets:</p>
<ul>
<li>Cốc Cốc</li>
<li>Timkhap</li>
<li>viet</li>
</ul>
<p>The first two terms are Vietnamese search engines, while the third term relates to any Vietnam-related searches. This specific focus on Vietnam's digital ecosystem demonstrates a clear and strategic targeting of the country's digital landscape.</p>
<p>The module uses this configuration to execute its core logic at runtime. If the HTTP request's <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">User-Agent</span> header matches a keyword from the same list, the module identifies the visitor as a search engine crawler and executes its poisoning phase. It contacts the C2 server to retrieve a malicious, SEO-optimized HTML webpage and serves it as the response.</p>
<p>Figure 2 displays an actual payload delivered by the C2 server. The payload contains the malicious HTML and a series of links that trick the search engine into scraping and indexing them.</p>
<figure id="attachment_158116" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-158116" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-158116 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-193333-158093-2.png" alt="A screenshot of a webpage filled with multiple hyperlinks in Vietnamese." width="1000" height="751" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-193333-158093-2.png 1098w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-193333-158093-2-586x440.png 586w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-193333-158093-2-932x700.png 932w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-193333-158093-2-768x577.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-158116" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. The SEO poison payload from the C2 server.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The mechanism first builds a lure and then springs the trap. The lure is built by attackers feeding manipulated content to search engine crawlers. This makes the compromised website rank for additional terms to which it would otherwise have no connection.</p>
<p>For instance, as Figure 2 above shows, the payload is filled with links containing popular Vietnamese search queries. A key example is <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">xôi lạc tv trực tiếp bóng đá hôm nay</span>, which translates to “xôi lạc tv live football today.” This is a popular search for an illegal soccer streaming service.</p>
<p>Ranking the compromised server for this term allows attackers to exploit its credibility and reputation. Figure 3 displays a Google search result for this string of terms, showing that a government entity in Southeast Asia was compromised to serve scam content.</p>
<figure id="attachment_158127" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-158127" style="width: 983px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-158127 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-196873-158093-3.png" alt="Screenshot of a website with a Vietnamese text headline, marked with an arrow pointing to the URL that has some redaction. The background features a graphic with a soccer theme and a casino advertisement." width="983" height="297" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-196873-158093-3.png 983w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-196873-158093-3-786x237.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-196873-158093-3-768x232.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 983px) 100vw, 983px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-158127" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. Google search index of a compromised government entity.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Conversely, when an incoming HTTP request's <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Referer</span> header contains any of the keywords from its configuration, the module flags it as a genuine user. In this case, the module contacts a C2 server and proxies its content directly to the victim's browser.</p>
<p>Figure 4 shows an actual proxied payload sent from the C2. This figure shows that the compromised web server redirects unsuspecting visitors to a betting site.</p>
<figure id="attachment_158138" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-158138" style="width: 737px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-158138 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-199778-158093-4.png" alt="Screenshot of a loading screen on gambling website, featuring a progress indicator at 1 second, Vietnamese text indicating 'Loading, please wait...,' and an English translation 'Loading, please wait patiently.' A button labeled 'Entering page' is displayed below." width="737" height="621" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-199778-158093-4.png 737w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-199778-158093-4-522x440.png 522w" sizes="(max-width: 737px) 100vw, 737px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-158138" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. The payload from the C2 server: a loading page that redirects visitors to a betting website.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-158093-_ht7vjz9uscc"></a>Additional Samples and Infrastructure</h3>
<p>A significant clue to the functionality and likely origin of the implant can be found in its C++ class name: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">chongxiede</span>. As noted above, this is the Chinese Pinyin transliteration for the word 重写 (chóng xiě), which machine translates to “rewrite” or “overwrite.” This linguistic artifact served as a pivot point in our investigation and allowed us to expand our research, ultimately leading us to additional samples and infrastructure-related threat activity.</p>
<p>We uncovered a suite of related native IIS modules that share handler registrations and initialization logic. Several of these new samples pointed to familiar C2 domains, variants of the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">008php[.]com</span> domain family, while others introduced previously unseen infrastructure. Figure 5 shows the infrastructure and the connections between the samples.</p>
<figure id="attachment_158149" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-158149" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-158149 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-202520-158093-5.png" alt="Diagram showing a network of connected domains with the central node labeled, surrounded by various other linked nodes with numerical and alphabetical domain names. Nodes are linked to malware represented by icons of bugs with skulls inside." width="1000" height="886" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-202520-158093-5.png 1309w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-202520-158093-5-497x440.png 497w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-202520-158093-5-790x700.png 790w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-202520-158093-5-768x681.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-158149" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. The newly found BadIIS samples and infrastructure.</figcaption></figure>
<p>We analyzed these related samples, then extracted and decrypted their embedded configurations. This analysis revealed a wider network of C2 servers and URLs that were not previously associated with this campaign. Our investigation into this newly discovered infrastructure revealed three additional variants, which demonstrate an expansion of the threat actor's toolkit, and capabilities beyond the native IIS module framework.</p>
<p>Because of the significance of the information gained from this linguistic artifact, we termed the campaign “Operation Rewrite.”</p>
<h2><a id="post-158093-_8x3hbfsa7nu2"></a>Three New Flavors for the BadIIS Module</h2>
<h3><a id="post-158093-_qv55tcy2ilsx"></a>First Variant: ASP.NET Gateway</h3>
<p>The first variant we discovered was not a native module at all, but a simple ASP.NET page handler. This script-based variant uses a different technique to achieve the same goal of SEO poisoning as the core BadIIS module.</p>
<p>Instead of hooking directly into the IIS pipeline, the ASP.NET page contains all the malicious logic within its <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Page_Load</span> event. When a victim requests the server for the page, the page checks the visitor's <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">HTTP_REFERER</span> to identify and redirect traffic from search engines, cloaking its real purpose. For all other traffic, it acts as a gateway, proxying malicious content from a remote C2 server.</p>
<p>This is a lighter, more flexible alternative to the main BadIIS module, likely for quick deployment on less-critical compromised servers. Figure 6 shows the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Page_Load</span> function of the ASP.NET variant.</p>
<figure id="attachment_158160" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-158160" style="width: 671px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-158160 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-205854-158093-6.png" alt="Screenshot of a programming code snippet involving logic for handling Twitter references and redirecting web traffic based on user-agent and referrer headers." width="671" height="638" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-205854-158093-6.png 671w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-205854-158093-6-463x440.png 463w" sizes="(max-width: 671px) 100vw, 671px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-158160" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. The <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Page_Load</span> function of the ASP.NET variant.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-158093-_e3xlvv6a2cf3"></a>Second Variant: Managed IIS Module</h3>
<p>The second variant achieved the same goal as the native IIS module, but it was implemented as a managed .NET IIS module. This C# variant leverages ASP.NET integration within IIS. It hooks into the server requests pipeline, granting it the ability to inspect and modify every request that passes through the application.</p>
<p>This module performs SEO poisoning through two primary functions:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>404 Error Hijacking</strong>: This module intercepts 404 errors when a search engine crawls a non-existent link containing keywords from a hard-coded list. It then serves a custom scam page from a C2 server, resulting in search engines indexing the attacker's content under the victim's trusted domain.</li>
<li><strong>Injecting Live Content</strong>: When the module detects a search engine crawler viewing a real page that returns a <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">200 OK</span> response, it dynamically injects spam links and keywords from a different C2 server. This action alters the existing page's search ranking, without changing the content that is visible to regular users.</li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-158093-_ljgosupb7bjy"></a>Third Variant: All-in-One PHP Script</h3>
<p>The third variant is a PHP-based script that combines user redirection and dynamic SEO poisoning. Rather than integrating into IIS, this script is a standalone PHP front-controller. It uses a simple referer, user agent and URL-pattern checks to decide exactly what to serve.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Checking mobile user requests</strong></li>
</ul>
<p>For visitors arriving from a Google search on a mobile device, the script performs an additional check. If the requested URL path contains a keyword from a hard-coded list (i.e., “game” or “video”) it acts as a proxy. The script silently contacts a hard-coded C2 URL, retrieves the content and serves it directly to the victim, who remains unaware of the substitution.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Poisoning Googlebot SEO</strong></li>
</ul>
<p>When the script detects Googlebot, it initiates a two-stage process to poison the site's search engine ranking.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<ul>
<li><strong>Sitemap generator</strong>: First, the script fetches a list of page names from the C2 server and presents them to Googlebot as a valid XML sitemap full of fake URLs.</li>
<li><strong>Content rewriter</strong>: When Googlebot crawls these fake URLs, the script's second stage activates, becoming a content rewriter. The script fetches an HTML template from another C2 and injects keywords from the URL into the page's title and headings. The result is an optimized spam page, designed to rank high in search results.</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<h2><a id="post-158093-_4ne3acq129gy"></a>Exploring the Threat Actors’ Origins</h2>
<p>We analyzed linguistic clues and infrastructure overlaps to determine the origins of the threat actors behind CL-UNK-1037. We attribute this activity cluster, with high confidence, to Chinese-speaking attackers. Additionally, we link this cluster with moderate confidence to Group 9 and with low confidence to DragonRank.</p>
<h3><a id="post-158093-_q4ruyf3l4cku"></a>Chinese-Speaking Threat Actors</h3>
<p>Several artifacts suggest the involvement of a Chinese-speaking threat actor. As stated previously, the native module's <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">chongxiede</span> object name is a Pinyin term. The PHP variant contained further linguistic evidence: numerous code comments written in simplified Chinese characters.</p>
<p>Figure 7 shows the comments written in simplified Chinese in the PHP variant, along with their English translations.</p>
<figure id="attachment_158171" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-158171" style="width: 708px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-158171 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-208515-158093-7.png" alt="Screenshot of a script checking the HTTP referrer and user agent to identify mobile devices and redirect based on specific conditions. Four sections are highlighted in red. " width="708" height="933" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-208515-158093-7.png 708w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-208515-158093-7-334x440.png 334w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-208515-158093-7-531x700.png 531w" sizes="(max-width: 708px) 100vw, 708px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-158171" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. The start of the PHP variant.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-158093-_sohaoo28olb"></a>Code Design and Infrastructure Overlaps with Group 9</h3>
<p>The BadIIS internal architecture design bears similarities to variants previously used by Group 9, as described by ESET in their whitepaper. These similarities include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Using the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">RegisterModule</span> function to initialize the module’s components</li>
<li>Using the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">OnBeginRequest</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">OnSendResponse</span> handlers to intercept and modify web traffic</li>
</ul>
<p>This parallel design suggests that the attackers are building their implants using a shared codebase or design pattern.</p>
<p>The direct overlap in C2 infrastructure across three separate domains solidifies the connection to Group 9. The C2 servers hard coded in the BadIIS samples included:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">404.008php[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">404.yyphw[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">404.300bt[.]com</span></li>
</ul>
<p>These servers directly correspond to domains used by Group 9. Specifically, ESET observed Group 9 using the following subdomains:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">qp.008php[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">fcp.yyphw[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">sc.300bt[.]com</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 8 illustrates this infrastructure.</p>
<figure id="attachment_158182" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-158182" style="width: 889px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-158182 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-211362-158093-8.png" alt="Diagram showing the infrastructure of the activity group named CL-UNK-1037 by PANW at top, connecting downwards to eleven nodes which further connect to a node labeled &quot;Group 9&quot; at the bottom. Each node is represented by a circle containing a gear icon with six cogs." width="889" height="909" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-211362-158093-8.png 889w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-211362-158093-8-430x440.png 430w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-211362-158093-8-685x700.png 685w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-211362-158093-8-768x785.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 889px) 100vw, 889px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-158182" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. The infrastructure overlaps between the new samples and Group 9.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-158093-_96cv64t1mkk6"></a>Possible Connection to DragonRank</h3>
<p>In addition to the direct links to Group 9, we observed several similarities to the DragonRank campaign. As detailed in Cisco's <a href="https://blog.talosintelligence.com/dragon-rank-seo-poisoning/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Talos article</a>, they attribute DragonRank to a Chinese-speaking threat actor that shares similarities with ESET's Group 9.</p>
<p>Although we found no infrastructure overlap between CL-UNK-1037 and the DragonRank campaign, we did observe the following similarities:</p>
<ul>
<li>Tool set: Similar core functionality and logical malware flow, using different implementations. Both variants are SEO and proxy tools.</li>
<li><strong>URI structure</strong>: A recurring <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">zz</span> pattern in the C2 URLs. While the pattern is used differently in each campaign, we assess that this could be the result of tool set evolution or upgrades over time.</li>
</ul>
<h2><a id="post-158093-_2an8ryq91inv"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>Our investigation into the Operation Rewrite SEO poisoning campaign uncovered a Chinese-speaking threat actor using a playbook of custom implants. The threat actor tailored all the implants to the goal of manipulating search engine results and controlling the flow of traffic.</p>
<p>We assess with high confidence that a Chinese-speaking actor is operating this activity, based on direct linguistic evidence, as well as infrastructure and architecture links between this actor and the Group 9 cluster. Our research also revealed several similarities with the DragonRank campaign.</p>
<p>Security teams and network defenders can leverage the analysis and indicators in this report to enhance their threat detection and hunting capabilities, strengthening their security against these and similar threats.</p>
<h3><a id="post-158093-_lsbythhc3nz9"></a>Palo Alto Networks Protection and Mitigation</h3>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-url-filtering/administration" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced DNS Security</a> identify known domains and URLs associated with this activity as malicious.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a> prevents the threats described in this blog by employing the Malware Prevention Engine. This approach combines several layers of protection, including <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a>, Behavioral Threat Protection and the Local Analysis module, to prevent both known and unknown malware from causing harm to endpoints.</li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America: Toll Free: +1 (866) 486-4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>UK: +44.20.3743.3660</li>
<li>Europe and Middle East: +31.20.299.3130</li>
<li>Asia: +65.6983.8730</li>
<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
<li>Australia: +61.2.4062.7950</li>
<li>India: 000 800 050 45107</li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the <a href="https://www.cyberthreatalliance.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber Threat Alliance</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-158093-_v8176g40kstn"></a>Indicators of Compromise</h2>
<p>BadIIS implants SHA256 hashes:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">01a616e25f1ac661a7a9c244fd31736188ceb5fce8c1a5738e807fdbef70fd60</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">bc3bba91572379e81919b9e4d2cbe3b0aa658a97af116e2385b99b610c22c08c</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">5aa684e90dd0b85f41383efe89dddb2d43ecbdaf9c1d52c40a2fdf037fb40138</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">c5455c43f6a295392cf7db66c68f8c725029f88e089ed01e3de858a114f0764f</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">82096c2716a4de687b3a09b638e39cc7c12959bf380610d5f8f9ac9cddab64d7</span></li>

<p>ASPX file handler SHA256 hash:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">b056197f093cd036fa509609d80ece307864806f52ab962901939b45718c18a8</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Managed IIS Module SHA256 hash:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">2af61e5acc4ca390d3bd43bc649ab30951ed7b4e36d58a05f5003d92fde5e9a7</span></li>
</ul>
<p>PHP file handler SHA256 hash:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">36bf18c3edd773072d412f4681fb25b1512d0d8a00aac36514cd6c48d80be71b</span></li>
</ul>
<p>C2 URLs:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://103.6.235[.]26/xvn.html</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://x404.008php[.]com/zz/u.php</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://103.6.235[.]78/vn.html</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://x404.008php[.]com/index.php</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://103.6.235[.]78/index.php</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://103.6.235[.]78/zz/u.php</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://cs.pyhycy[.]com/index.php</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://cs.pyhycy[.]com/zz/u.php</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://sl.008php[.]com/kt.html</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://160.30.173[.]87/zz/u.php</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://404.pyhycy[.]com/index.php</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://404.pyhycy[.]com/zz/u.php</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://404.hao563[.]com/index.php</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://404.300bt[.]com/zz/u.php</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://404.yyphw[.]com/index.php</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://103.6.235[.]26/kt.html</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://404.yyphw[.]com/zz/u.php</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://404.hzyzn[.]com/index.php</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://404.hzyzn[.]com/zz/u.php</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://404.300bt[.]com/index.php</span></li>

<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://103.248.20[.]197/zz/u.php</span></li>

</ul>
<h2><a id="post-158093-_570cbe1pdhwx"></a>Additional Resources</h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://web-assets.esetstatic.com/wls/2021/08/eset_anatomy_native_iis_malware.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">ANATOMY OF NATIVE IIS MALWARE [PDF]</a> – Eset</li>
<li><a href="https://blog.talosintelligence.com/dragon-rank-seo-poisoning/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">DragonRank, a Chinese-speaking SEO manipulator service provider</a> – Talos, Cisco</li>
<li><a href="https://sec.vnpt.vn/2024/09/part-2-hacker-thuc-hien-black-hat-seo-cac-trang-web-bat-hop-phap-bang-tan-cong-redirect-nhu-the-nao" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Hacker thực hiện Black Hat SEO các trang web bất hợp pháp bằng tấn công Redirect như thế nào ?</a> – VNPT</li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
